text: Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack): Defined as the irreversible necrosis of heart muscle secondary to prolonged ischemia. Causes usually involve the rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque leading to coronary artery thrombosis. Main symptoms include severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left arm or jaw, diaphoresis, and dyspnea. Diagnosis is confirmed via ECG changes (ST-elevation) and elevated cardiac troponins. Standard treatment involves reperfusion therapy (PCI or thrombolysis), antiplatelet agents (aspirin, P2Y12 inhibitors), and anticoagulation.

Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: A metabolic disorder characterized by hyperglycemia resulting from insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency. Risk factors include obesity, physical inactivity, and genetics. Symptoms include polydipsia, polyuria, unexplained weight loss, and blurred vision. Diagnosis is based on HbA1c levels >= 6.5% or fasting plasma glucose >= 126 mg/dL. Treatment begins with lifestyle modifications and Metformin, progressing to other oral antidiabetics (SGLT2 inhibitors, GLP-1 agonists) or insulin if refractory.

Asthma: A chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, airflow obstruction, and bronchial hyperresponsiveness. Causes include genetic predisposition and environmental triggers like allergens or pollution. Symptoms are wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, and coughing. Diagnosis involves spirometry showing reversible airflow limitation (improvement with bronchodilator). Treatment follows a step-wise approach using inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and long-acting beta-agonists (LABA), with short-acting beta-agonists (SABA) for acute relief.

Alzheimer's Disease: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder and the most common cause of dementia, characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-beta plaques and tau tangles. The primary risk factor is age. Symptoms include short-term memory loss, confusion, language difficulties, and behavioral changes. Diagnosis is clinical, supported by cognitive testing (MMSE) and neuroimaging (MRI/PET) to rule out other causes. Current treatment is symptomatic, utilizing cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil) and NMDA receptor antagonists (memantine).

Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): A digestive disorder where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining. Caused by a weak lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, dysphagia, and chronic cough. Diagnosis is often clinical or confirmed via upper endoscopy and pH monitoring. Treatment involves lifestyle changes (weight loss, elevating head during sleep), proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), and H2 blockers. Surgery (Nissen fundoplication) is reserved for refractory cases.

Rheumatoid Arthritis: An autoimmune disease resulting in chronic systemic inflammation primarily affecting flexible joints. Causes involve a complex interplay of genetic (HLA-DRB1) and environmental factors. Symptoms include tender, warm, swollen joints, joint stiffness usually worse in the mornings and after inactivity, and fatigue. Diagnosis includes elevated Rheumatoid Factor (RF), anti-CCP antibodies, and elevated ESR/CRP. Treatment aims to induce remission using DMARDs (methotrexate), biologics (TNF inhibitors), and NSAIDs for pain control.

"Acute Otitis Media: An infection of the middle ear, common in children. Often caused by bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae following a viral URI. Symptoms include otalgia (ear pain), fever, irritability, and temporary hearing loss. Diagnosis is made via otoscopy showing a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with reduced mobility. Treatment involves pain management (analgesics) and observation ("watchful waiting"); antibiotics (amoxicillin) are prescribed for severe cases or young children."

Psoriasis: An immune-mediated disease that causes raised, red, scaly patches to appear on the skin. The underlying mechanism involves accelerated skin cell turnover. Triggers include stress, infections, and cold weather. Symptoms present as red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales, dry cracked skin, and itching. Diagnosis is typically clinical based on appearance. Treatment ranges from topical corticosteroids and vitamin D analogs to phototherapy and systemic biologics for extensive disease.

Major Depressive Disorder: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. Causes are multifactorial, involving biological, psychological, and social sources of distress. Symptoms include feelings of sadness, changes in appetite or sleep, fatigue, and suicidal ideation. Diagnosis requires criteria from DSM-5. Treatment involves psychotherapy (CBT), pharmacotherapy (SSRIs, SNRIs), or a combination of both.

Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD): A longstanding disease of the kidneys leading to renal failure. Common causes are diabetes and hypertension. Symptoms are often absent in early stages; late stages present with edema, fatigue, nausea, and hematuria. Diagnosis is based on eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73m2 for three months and albuminuria. Treatment focuses on managing underlying causes (blood pressure and glucose control) and complications; end-stage renal disease requires dialysis or kidney transplantation.

Appendicitis: Inflammation of the appendix. Typically caused by obstruction of the appendiceal lumen by a fecalith or lymphoid hyperplasia. Symptoms usually start with periumbilical pain migrating to the right lower quadrant, nausea, vomiting, and fever. Diagnosis involves physical signs (McBurney's point tenderness) and imaging (CT scan or Ultrasound). Standard treatment is surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy) and prophylactic antibiotics.

Glaucoma: A group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often caused by abnormally high pressure in the eye. It is a leading cause of blindness for people over 60. Symptoms in open-angle glaucoma are slow loss of peripheral vision; acute angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe eye pain, blurred vision, and halos around lights. Diagnosis involves tonometry (IOP measurement) and optic nerve imaging. Treatment includes prostaglandin analog eye drops, laser trabeculoplasty, or surgery to lower intraocular pressure.

Iron Deficiency Anemia: A condition where blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells due to insufficient iron. Causes include blood loss (menstruation, ulcers), poor diet, or inability to absorb iron. Symptoms include extreme fatigue, weakness, pale skin, chest pain, and cold hands/feet. Diagnosis is confirmed by CBC showing low Hemoglobin and MCV, and low serum ferritin levels. Treatment involves oral iron supplements and addressing the underlying cause of blood loss.

Hypothyroidism: A condition in which the thyroid gland usually does not produce enough thyroid hormone. The most common cause is Hashimoto's thyroiditis (autoimmune). Symptoms include fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, constipation, dry skin, and weight gain. Diagnosis is confirmed by high TSH levels and low Free T4 levels in the blood. Standard treatment involves daily use of the synthetic thyroid hormone levothyroxine to restore adequate hormone levels.

Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): An infection in any part of the urinary system, usually the bladder and urethra. Most often caused by E. coli bacteria. Symptoms include a strong urge to urinate, burning sensation when urinating, and cloudy or strong-smelling urine. Diagnosis is via urinalysis (leukocyte esterase, nitrites) and urine culture. Treatment typically involves a short course of antibiotics such as nitrofurantoin or trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.

Migraine: A neurological condition characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Causes are believed to be genetic and environmental. Symptoms include severe throbbing pain usually on one side of the head, nausea, and sensitivity to light (photophobia) and sound. Diagnosis is based on clinical history and exclusion of other headaches. Treatment includes abortive medications (triptans, NSAIDs) and preventive medications (beta-blockers, topiramate, CGRP inhibitors).

Celiac Disease: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. In affected individuals, eating gluten triggers an immune response in the small intestine. Symptoms include diarrhea, bloating, gas, fatigue, and weight loss. Diagnosis involves serologic tests (tTG-IgA) followed by a duodenal biopsy. The only effective treatment is a strict, lifelong gluten-free diet.

Endometriosis: A disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of the uterus grows outside the uterus. The exact cause is unknown but may involve retrograde menstruation. Symptoms involve pelvic pain (often associated with menstruation), pain with intercourse, and infertility. Diagnosis is suspected clinically but confirmed via laparoscopy. Treatment includes pain medication, hormonal therapy (birth control pills, GnRH agonists), or surgery to remove tissue.

Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The formation of a blood clot in a deep vein, most commonly in the legs. Risk factors include prolonged immobility, surgery, and malignancy. Symptoms include swelling in the affected leg, pain/cramping, and red or discolored skin. Diagnosis is performed via compression ultrasonography and D-dimer testing. Treatment focuses on anticoagulation (heparin, warfarin, DOACs) to prevent the clot from growing or traveling to the lungs (pulmonary embolism).

Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): An irregular and often very rapid heart rhythm (arrhythmia) that can lead to blood clots in the heart. Causes include hypertension, heart defects, and stimulant use. Symptoms are palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Diagnosis is confirmed by Electrocardiogram (ECG) showing absent P-waves and irregular R-R intervals. Treatment focuses on rate control (beta-blockers), rhythm control (antiarrhythmics), and stroke prevention via anticoagulants.

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Primary cause is long-term exposure to irritating gases or particulate matter, most often from cigarette smoke. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing. Diagnosis is confirmed via Spirometry. Treatment involves smoking cessation, bronchodilators, inhaled steroids, and oxygen therapy in severe cases.

Parkinson's Disease: A progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement, caused by the loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra. Symptoms include tremors (resting), bradykinesia (slowness of movement), limb rigidity, and gait/balance problems. Diagnosis is clinical, based on symptoms and response to medication. Standard treatment involves Levodopa/Carbidopa to replenish dopamine and dopamine agonists.

Crohn's Disease: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes inflammation of the digestive tract, which can lead to abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. The exact cause is immune-mediated. Diagnosis involves colonoscopy with biopsy and imaging (CT/MRI enterography). Treatment includes corticosteroids for flares, immunomodulators, and biologic therapies (anti-TNF agents) to maintain remission.

Bipolar Disorder: A mental health condition that causes extreme mood swings that include emotional highs (mania or hypomania) and lows (depression). Biological differences and genetics play a role. Symptoms range from racing thoughts and risky behavior in mania to hopelessness in depression. Diagnosis is clinical per DSM-5 criteria. Treatment typically involves mood stabilizers (Lithium, Valproate), antipsychotics, and psychotherapy.

Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema): A condition that makes skin red and itchy. It is common in children but can occur at any age. Associated with a variation in the FLG gene and immune system dysfunction. Symptoms include dry skin, severe itching (especially at night), and red to brownish-gray patches. Diagnosis is usually clinical. Treatment includes avoiding triggers, daily moisturizing, topical corticosteroids, and calcineurin inhibitors.

Hyperthyroidism (Graves' Disease): An immune system disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis). Caused by thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI). Symptoms include weight loss despite increased appetite, rapid heartbeat, sweating, and tremors. Diagnosis is based on low TSH and high Free T4 levels. Treatment options are antithyroid medications (methimazole), radioactive iodine therapy, or thyroidectomy.

Cataracts: Clouding of the normally clear lens of the eye. Most cataracts develop slowly over the course of aging. Symptoms include clouded or blurred vision, increasing difficulty with vision at night, sensitivity to light and glare, and fading of colors. Diagnosis is performed via a slit-lamp examination. The only effective treatment is surgery to remove the clouded lens and replace it with an artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

Acute Sinusitis: Inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses. Often caused by the common cold (viral) or bacterial infection. Symptoms include thick yellow/green nasal discharge, nasal congestion, pain/tenderness around eyes and cheeks, and headache. Diagnosis is clinical; CT scans are used for chronic cases. Treatment involves saline irrigation, nasal corticosteroids, and antibiotics if symptoms persist beyond 10 days.

Hepatitis C: A viral infection that causes liver inflammation, sometimes leading to serious liver damage. Transmitted through contaminated blood. Many people have no symptoms until liver damage manifests; late symptoms include jaundice, fatigue, and easy bleeding. Diagnosis is via HCV antibody test followed by PCR RNA test. Standard treatment is now highly effective using Direct-Acting Antivirals (DAAs) for 8-12 weeks.

Herniated Disc: A condition where the soft center of a spinal disc pushes through a crack in the tougher exterior casing. Causes include age-related wear and tear or strain. Symptoms are arm or leg pain (radiculopathy), numbness, and weakness in muscles served by the affected nerve. Diagnosis is confirmed by MRI of the spine. Treatment ranges from physical therapy and NSAIDs to epidural steroid injections or surgery (discectomy) for severe cases.

Sickle Cell Anemia: An inherited red blood cell disorder in which there aren't enough healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen throughout the body. Caused by a mutation in the hemoglobin-Beta gene. Symptoms include episodes of pain (crises), swelling of hands and feet, and frequent infections. Diagnosis is via hemoglobin electrophoresis. Treatment includes hydration, pain management, hydroxyurea, and blood transfusions.

Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH): Age-associated prostate gland enlargement that can cause urination difficulty. It is not cancer. Symptoms include frequent or urgent need to urinate, nocturia, weak urine stream, or inability to completely empty the bladder. Diagnosis includes Digital Rectal Exam (DRE) and PSA test to rule out cancer. Treatment includes alpha-blockers to relax muscles, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors to shrink the prostate, or surgical resection (TURP).

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): An autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. Symptoms vary but often include a butterfly rash on the face, joint pain, fatigue, and photosensitivity. Diagnosis is complex, involving ANA tests and specific antibodies (Anti-dsDNA). Treatment involves hydroxychloroquine, corticosteroids, and immunosuppressants.

Tuberculosis (TB): A potentially serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs. Caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Symptoms include a persistent cough lasting three weeks or more, coughing up blood, chest pain, weight loss, and night sweats. Diagnosis is via Tuberculin skin test, IGRA blood test, and Chest X-ray. Treatment requires a long course (6-9 months) of multiple antibiotics (RIPE: Rifampin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol).

Gallstones (Cholelithiasis): Hardened deposits of digestive fluid that can form in the gallbladder. Causes include excess cholesterol or bilirubin in bile. Symptoms include sudden and intensifying pain in the upper right abdomen, back pain, and nausea. Diagnosis is typically confirmed by abdominal ultrasound. Treatment is usually surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy) if the stones cause symptoms.

Schizophrenia: A serious mental disorder in which people interpret reality abnormally. Exact causes are unknown but involve genetics and brain chemistry. Symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking (speech), and negative symptoms (reduced ability to function). Diagnosis is based on DSM-5 criteria observing symptoms for at least 6 months. Treatment requires lifelong management with antipsychotic medications and psychosocial therapy.

Melanoma: The most serious type of skin cancer, developing in the cells (melanocytes) that produce melanin. Major risk factor is UV radiation exposure. Symptoms include a change in an existing mole or the development of a new pigmented or unusual-looking growth (ABCDE rule: Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolving). Diagnosis is via excisional biopsy. Treatment involves surgical excision, lymph node dissection, and immunotherapy or targeted therapy for metastatic disease.

Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): A chronic condition in which the heart doesn't pump blood as well as it should. Causes include CAD, hypertension, and valve conditions. Symptoms are shortness of breath (dyspnea), fatigue, and swelling (edema) in the legs and feet. Diagnosis involves Echocardiogram and BNP blood test. Treatment includes ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics to reduce fluid, and lifestyle changes like low-sodium diet.

Gout: A common and complex form of arthritis characterized by sudden, severe attacks of pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness in one or more joints, most often in the big toe. Caused by hyperuricemia (high uric acid) forming urate crystals in the joint. Diagnosis involves joint fluid aspiration showing crystals. Treatment for acute attacks includes NSAIDs and colchicine; chronic management involves allopurinol to lower uric acid.

Multiple Sclerosis (MS): An autoimmune disease of the central nervous system where the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers. Causes are unknown but involve genetic and environmental factors. Symptoms vary widely but include numbness, tremor, vision problems, and fatigue. Diagnosis is supported by MRI showing lesions and lumbar puncture. Treatment focuses on speeding recovery from attacks (steroids) and slowing progression (interferons, ocrelizumab).

Pneumonia: An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid or pus. Caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. Symptoms include cough with phlegm, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. Diagnosis is confirmed by chest X-ray and physical exam (crackles). Treatment depends on the cause; bacterial pneumonia is treated with antibiotics (azithromycin, amoxicillin), while viral requires supportive care.

Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): A mental health disorder characterized by persistent and excessive worry about a number of different things. Causes involve brain chemistry and life experiences. Symptoms include restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and muscle tension. Diagnosis is based on clinical history (DSM-5). Treatment includes psychotherapy (CBT) and medications such as SSRIs or benzodiazepines for short-term relief.

Acne Vulgaris: A skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become plugged with oil and dead skin cells. Driven by hormonal changes and bacteria (Cutibacterium acnes). Symptoms include whiteheads, blackheads, and pimples, usually on the face, forehead, chest, and back. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment ranges from topical retinoids and benzoyl peroxide to oral antibiotics (doxycycline) or isotretinoin for severe nodular acne.

Pulmonary Embolism (PE): A blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by blood clots that travel to the lungs from the legs (DVT). Symptoms include sudden shortness of breath, chest pain that worsens when breathing in, and cough producing bloody sputum. Diagnosis is via CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA). Treatment requires immediate anticoagulation (heparin, apixaban) or thrombolytic therapy for life-threatening cases.

Cirrhosis: Late-stage scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions, such as hepatitis and chronic alcoholism. Symptoms are initially absent but progress to fatigue, jaundice, ascites (fluid in abdomen), and confusion (encephalopathy). Diagnosis involves liver function tests, imaging (elastography), and biopsy. Treatment prevents further damage but liver transplant is the only cure for end-stage failure.

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: A condition that causes numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hand due to pressure on the median nerve in the wrist. Risk factors include repetitive hand motions and anatomy. Symptoms are numbness or pain in the thumb and first three fingers, often at night. Diagnosis uses physical tests (Phalen's maneuver) and nerve conduction studies. Treatment includes wrist splinting, corticosteroids, and surgical release of the transverse carpal ligament.

Insomnia Disorder: A sleep disorder characterized by difficulty falling and/or staying asleep. Causes include stress, irregular sleep schedule, and mental health disorders. Symptoms include daytime sleepiness, irritability, and problems with focus. Diagnosis is clinical, sometimes aided by a sleep diary or polysomnography. Treatment emphasizes sleep hygiene and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I), with short-term use of sedatives (zolpidem) if necessary.

Breast Cancer: Cancer that forms in the cells of the breasts. Risk factors include genetics (BRCA1/2 mutations), age, and estrogen exposure. Symptoms include a breast lump, change in size/shape, or nipple discharge. Diagnosis involves mammography, ultrasound, and core needle biopsy. Treatment is multimodal: surgery (lumpectomy/mastectomy), chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and hormonal therapy (tamoxifen, aromatase inhibitors).

Epilepsy: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior and loss of awareness. Causes can be genetic, head trauma, or stroke. Diagnosis is confirmed by Electroencephalogram (EEG) showing abnormal brain wave patterns. Treatment primarily involves anti-seizure medications (levetiracetam, valproate); surgery or neurostimulation are options for drug-resistant cases.

Diverticulitis: Inflammation or infection of small pouches (diverticula) that can form in the lining of the digestive system. Risk factors include age and low-fiber diet. Symptoms include severe pain in the lower left abdomen, fever, nausea, and change in bowel habits. Diagnosis is confirmed by CT scan of the abdomen. Treatment ranges from rest and oral antibiotics (ciprofloxacin/metronidazole) to intravenous antibiotics and surgery for complications like perforation.

Malaria: A life-threatening disease caused by parasites that are transmitted to people through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. Symptoms include high fevers, shaking chills, and flu-like illness. Diagnosis is made by examining a blood smear under a microscope for parasites. Treatment involves antimalarial drugs such as artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) or chloroquine, depending on parasite resistance.

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD): A chronic disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, reoccurring thoughts (obsessions) and/or behaviors (compulsions) that he or she feels the urge to repeat. Biology and environment play a role. Symptoms include fear of germs, need for symmetry, and excessive cleaning or checking. Diagnosis is clinical per DSM-5. Treatment combines Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) therapy and medications (SSRIs).

Glomerulonephritis: Inflammation of the tiny filters in the kidneys (glomeruli). It can be acute or chronic, caused by infections (strep throat), lupus, or unknown factors. Symptoms include pink or cola-colored urine (hematuria), foamy urine (proteinuria), and hypertension. Diagnosis involves urinalysis and kidney biopsy. Treatment focuses on the underlying cause, often using corticosteroids and immunosuppressants to reduce inflammation.

Rotator Cuff Tear: A tear in the tissues connecting muscle to bone (tendons) around the shoulder joint. Caused by injury or degeneration. Symptoms include a dull ache deep in the shoulder, arm weakness, and difficulty raising the arm. Diagnosis is confirmed via MRI or ultrasound. Treatment typically begins with physical therapy and anti-inflammatory drugs; surgical repair is necessary for complete tears or failed conservative management.

Tinnitus: The perception of noise or ringing in the ears when no external sound is present. It is a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury, or circulatory system disorder. Diagnosis involves audiological exams to check hearing and imaging (MRI) to rule out tumors. Treatment treats the underlying cause; management strategies include masking devices, hearing aids, and cognitive behavioral therapy.

Acute Pancreatitis: Sudden inflammation of the pancreas. The most common causes are gallstones and excessive alcohol intake. Symptoms include severe upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting, and fever. Diagnosis requires 2 of 3: characteristic pain, elevated lipase/amylase levels (3x normal), and imaging findings (CT). Treatment is supportive: IV fluids, pain management, and bowel rest (NPO) until inflammation subsides.

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD): A mental health condition that's triggered by a terrifying event â€” either experiencing it or witnessing it. Symptoms include flashbacks, nightmares, severe anxiety, and uncontrollable thoughts about the event. Diagnosis is based on specific symptom criteria lasting over a month. Treatment involves trauma-focused psychotherapies (EMDR, CPT) and medications like SSRIs (sertraline, paroxetine).

Hemorrhoids: Swollen veins in the lowest part of the rectum and anus. Causes include straining during bowel movements and pregnancy. Symptoms include bleeding during bowel movements, itching, and pain. Diagnosis is by visual inspection and anoscopy. Treatment includes high-fiber diet, topical creams, sitz baths, and procedures like rubber band ligation or surgical hemorrhoidectomy for severe cases.

Ischemic Stroke: A medical emergency where blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen. Most often caused by a thrombus or embolus. Symptoms include sudden numbness (face/arm/leg), confusion, trouble speaking, and vision loss (FAST). Diagnosis is immediate via CT or MRI of the brain. Treatment involves tPA (clot-buster) if within the window, or mechanical thrombectomy.

Sepsis: A life-threatening condition that arises when the body's response to an infection causes injury to its own tissues and organs. Bacterial infections are the most common cause. Symptoms include fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and confusion. Diagnosis involves blood cultures, lactate levels, and SOFA score assessment. Treatment requires rapid administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and intravenous fluids.

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD): Open sores that develop on the inside lining of the stomach and the upper portion of the small intestine. Causes include H. pylori infection and long-term use of NSAIDs. Symptoms are burning stomach pain, feeling of fullness, and intolerance to fatty foods. Diagnosis is confirmed via Upper Endoscopy (EGD). Treatment includes Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) and antibiotics to eradicate H. pylori.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Associated with excess androgen levels. Symptoms include irregular periods, excess hair growth (hirsutism), acne, and obesity. Diagnosis involves pelvic ultrasound and blood tests for hormone levels. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms via birth control pills, metformin, and lifestyle changes.

Lyme Disease: A vector-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted by the bite of an infected black-legged tick. Symptoms typically begin with a bull's-eye rash (erythema migrans), fever, fatigue, and joint pain. Diagnosis is serological (ELISA followed by Western Blot). Standard treatment is a course of oral antibiotics, typically doxycycline or amoxicillin.

Scoliosis: A sideways curvature of the spine that most often occurs during the growth spurt just before puberty. The cause is often idiopathic. Symptoms include uneven shoulders, one shoulder blade that appears more prominent than the other, and uneven waist. Diagnosis is confirmed by X-rays measuring the Cobb angle. Treatment ranges from observation and bracing to spinal fusion surgery for severe curves.

Anorexia Nervosa: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, an intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of weight. Causes are psychological, environmental, and biological. Symptoms include extreme weight loss, fatigue, dizziness, and refusal to eat. Diagnosis is based on physical exam and psychological evaluation (DSM-5). Treatment involves nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy.

Kidney Stones (Nephrolithiasis): Hard deposits made of minerals and salts that form inside the kidneys. Causes include low water intake, diet, and certain supplements. Symptoms are severe pain in the side and back (renal colic), pink/red urine, and nausea. Diagnosis is via CT scan or Ultrasound. Treatment involves hydration and pain medication for small stones; larger stones require lithotripsy or surgical removal.

Cystic Fibrosis: A hereditary disease that affects the lungs and digestive system. Caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene leading to thick, sticky mucus production. Symptoms include persistent cough, frequent lung infections, wheezing, and poor growth. Diagnosis is via the sweat chloride test and genetic testing. Treatment involves chest physical therapy, bronchodilators, and CFTR modulator therapies.

Rosacea: A common skin condition that causes redness and visible blood vessels in the face. The cause is unknown but involves immune and neurovascular factors. Symptoms include facial redness, swollen red bumps, and eye problems. Diagnosis is clinical based on appearance. Treatment includes topical drugs (metronidazole, ivermectin), oral antibiotics for inflammation, and laser therapy for visible vessels.

Tetanus: A serious bacterial infection that causes painful muscle spasms and can lead to death. Caused by Clostridium tetani toxin entering through a wound. Symptoms include jaw cramping (lockjaw), muscle stiffness, and trouble swallowing. Diagnosis is clinical based on history and signs. Treatment involves tetanus antitoxin (TIG), antibiotics, vaccine booster, and supportive care in an ICU.

Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD): A common circulatory problem in which narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs. Caused by atherosclerosis. Symptoms include leg pain when walking (claudication), numbness, and coldness in the lower leg. Diagnosis involves Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) and ultrasound. Treatment includes lifestyle changes, statins, antiplatelet agents, and sometimes angioplasty.

Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD): An eye disease that blurs the sharp, central vision needed for activities like reading. It damages the macula. Symptoms include distorted vision and a dark, empty area in the center of vision. Diagnosis is via dilated eye exam and OCT imaging. Treatment for the 'wet' type involves anti-VEGF injections; 'dry' type is managed with specific vitamin formulations (AREDS2).

Hodgkin Lymphoma: A cancer of the lymphatic system. It is distinguished by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Symptoms include painless swelling of lymph nodes in the neck, armpits or groin, persistent fatigue, and fever. Diagnosis is confirmed by lymph node biopsy. Treatment is highly effective and typically involves chemotherapy (e.g., ABVD regimen) and radiation therapy.

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS): A common disorder that affects the large intestine. It is a functional gastrointestinal disorder. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation. Diagnosis is a diagnosis of exclusion and Rome IV criteria. Treatment focuses on diet (low FODMAP), stress management, and medications like antispasmodics or laxatives.

Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD): A chronic condition including attention difficulty, hyperactivity, and impulsiveness. Causes involve brain anatomy and neurotransmitter regulation. Symptoms include difficulty sustaining attention, fidgeting, and excessive talking. Diagnosis involves clinical interview and rating scales. Treatment includes stimulants (methylphenidate, amphetamines) and behavioral therapy.

Scabies: An itchy skin infestation caused by a microscopic burrowing mite called Sarcoptes scabiei. It spreads quickly through close physical contact. Symptoms include intense itching (worse at night) and a pimple-like rash with thin, irregular burrow tracks. Diagnosis is usually clinical or via skin scraping. Treatment involves prescription creams (permethrin) or oral ivermectin; contacts must also be treated.

Meningitis: Inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Can be viral, bacterial, or fungal. Symptoms include sudden high fever, stiff neck, and severe headache. Diagnosis is via Lumbar Puncture (spinal tap) to analyze CSF. Treatment depends on cause; bacterial meningitis is a medical emergency requiring intravenous antibiotics and corticosteroids.

Addison's Disease: A disorder in which the adrenal glands don't produce enough hormones. Caused by autoimmune damage to the adrenal cortex. Symptoms include extreme fatigue, weight loss, darkening of the skin (hyperpigmentation), and low blood pressure. Diagnosis is via blood tests (low sodium, high potassium, low cortisol) and ACTH stimulation test. Treatment involves hormone replacement therapy (hydrocortisone/fludrocortisone).

Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA): An enlargement of the aorta, the main blood vessel that delivers blood to the body, at the level of the abdomen. Risk factors include smoking and atherosclerosis. Often asymptomatic until rupture; symptoms may include a pulsating feeling near the navel or deep back pain. Diagnosis is via abdominal ultrasound or CT. Treatment depends on size; surveillance for small AAAs, endovascular repair (EVAR) or open surgery for large ones.

Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA): A sleep disorder where throat muscles intermittently relax and block the airway during sleep. Risk factors include obesity and neck circumference. Symptoms include loud snoring, gasping for air during sleep, and excessive daytime sleepiness. Diagnosis is confirmed by Polysomnography (sleep study). Treatment involves weight loss and Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy.

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD): A developmental disability caused by differences in the brain. Characteristics include challenges with social communication, restricted interests, and repetitive behaviors. Signs often appear in early childhood. Diagnosis is based on developmental monitoring and comprehensive behavioral evaluation. Treatment focuses on behavioral therapies (e.g., ABA), speech therapy, and occupational therapy.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL): A cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells. It is the most common childhood cancer. Caused by DNA mutations in bone marrow cells. Symptoms include pale skin, frequent infections, bruising, and bone pain. Diagnosis involves Complete Blood Count (CBC) and bone marrow aspiration. Treatment typically consists of chemotherapy, targeted drugs, and stem cell transplantation.

Urticaria (Hives): A skin reaction that causes itchy welts. Can be triggered by food, medication, or stress, leading to histamine release. Symptoms are raised, red or skin-colored welts (wheals) that turn white when pressed and severe itching. Diagnosis is clinical; allergy testing is used for recurrent cases. Treatment involves oral antihistamines and avoiding triggers; severe cases may require corticosteroids.

Cluster Headache: A neurological disorder characterized by recurrent, severe headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye. Attacks occur in clusters (cycles). Symptoms include intense burning/piercing pain, tearing, and nasal congestion on the affected side. Diagnosis is based on distinct clinical patterns. Treatment includes high-flow oxygen and triptans for acute attacks, and verapamil for prevention.

HIV/AIDS: A virus that attacks the body's immune system, specifically CD4 cells. Transmitted via bodily fluids. Symptoms start with flu-like illness, progressing to weight loss and opportunistic infections if untreated. Diagnosis is via antigen/antibody tests and viral load measurement. Treatment is Antiretroviral Therapy (ART), which suppresses the virus to undetectable levels, allowing patients to live normal lives.

Viral Gastroenteritis (Stomach Flu): An intestinal infection marked by watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea or vomiting, and sometimes fever. Common causes are Norovirus and Rotavirus. Spread through contact or contaminated food/water. Diagnosis is usually clinical. Treatment is supportive, focusing on hydration and electrolyte replacement; antibiotics are ineffective against viruses.

Plantar Fasciitis: Inflammation of a thick band of tissue (plantar fascia) that connects the heel bone to the toes. Causes include overuse, obesity, and foot mechanics. Symptoms include stabbing pain near the heel, usually worst with the first steps in the morning. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves stretching exercises, orthotics, NSAIDs, and in refractory cases, steroid injections.

Myasthenia Gravis: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles. Caused by antibodies blocking acetylcholine receptors. Symptoms include droopy eyelids (ptosis), double vision, and difficulty swallowing or breathing. Diagnosis is confirmed by blood tests for antibodies and nerve stimulation tests. Treatment includes anticholinesterase medications (pyridostigmine), corticosteroids, and thymectomy.

Cushing's Syndrome: A condition that occurs from exposure to high cortisol levels for a long time. Causes include long-term steroid use or a pituitary tumor (Cushing's disease). Symptoms include a fatty hump between shoulders, a rounded face (moon face), and pink stretch marks. Diagnosis is via 24-hour urine cortisol or dexamethasone suppression test. Treatment depends on cause (e.g., surgery for tumors, tapering steroids).

Varicose Veins: Gnarled, enlarged veins, most commonly appearing in the legs and feet. Caused by weak or damaged vein valves permitting backflow. Symptoms include dark purple veins, heavy feeling in legs, burning, and swelling. Diagnosis is by physical exam and Duplex Ultrasound. Treatment ranges from compression stockings to sclerotherapy or laser ablation procedures.

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): One of the most common causes of vertigo. Caused by calcium crystals (otoconia) dislodging into the semicircular canals of the inner ear. Symptoms include brief episodes of mild to intense dizziness triggered by specific changes in head position. Diagnosis is via the Dix-Hallpike test. Treatment involves canalith repositioning procedures like the Epley maneuver.

Sarcoidosis: An inflammatory disease characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells (granulomas) in any part of the body, most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes. Cause is unknown. Symptoms include persistent dry cough, shortness of breath, and reddish-purple skin bumps. Diagnosis involves chest X-ray and biopsy. Treatment often involves corticosteroids if organs are threatened, though some cases resolve spontaneously.

Hemophilia A: A genetic disorder caused by missing or defective factor VIII, a clotting protein. It is X-linked recessive. Symptoms include unexplained and excessive bleeding from cuts, pain/swelling in joints (hemarthrosis), and large bruises. Diagnosis is by clotting factor assays. Treatment involves regular replacement therapy with clotting factor concentrates.

Prostatitis: Swelling and inflammation of the prostate gland. Can be bacterial or chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Symptoms include painful or difficult urination, pain in the groin/pelvic area, and flu-like symptoms (if acute bacterial). Diagnosis involves urinalysis and digital rectal exam. Treatment for bacterial causes involves prolonged antibiotics; alpha-blockers are used for chronic pain.

Vitiligo: A disease that causes the loss of skin color in blotches. Occurs when pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) die or stop functioning. Symptoms include patchy loss of skin color, premature whitening of hair, and loss of color in mucous membranes. Diagnosis is clinical, sometimes with a Wood's lamp exam. Treatment includes corticosteroid creams, phototherapy (UVB), and depigmentation for extensive cases.

Pancreatic Cancer: Cancer that begins in the organ lying behind the lower part of the stomach. Risk factors include smoking and diabetes. Symptoms often appear late and include jaundice, dark urine, unintended weight loss, and back pain. Diagnosis is via CT scan, MRI, and EUS-guided biopsy. Treatment options are limited but include the Whipple procedure (surgery), chemotherapy, and radiation.

Infectious Mononucleosis: Often called the kissing disease. The virus that causes mono is transmitted through saliva. Most often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Symptoms include extreme fatigue, fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Diagnosis is via the Monospot test or antibody blood tests. Treatment is supportive: rest, fluids, and OTC pain relievers.

Fibromyalgia: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. The mechanism involves central sensitization. Symptoms include dull ache all over the body and cognitive difficulties (fibro fog). Diagnosis is clinical based on widespread pain index. Treatment combines medications (antidepressants, anticonvulsants) with physical therapy and stress reduction.

Alopecia Areata: An autoimmune disorder that causes hair to fall out, often in clumps the size and shape of a quarter. The immune system attacks hair follicles. Symptoms are smooth, round hairless patches on the scalp or body. Diagnosis is usually clinical. Treatment includes intralesional corticosteroid injections and topical minoxidil.

Conjunctivitis (Pink Eye): Inflammation or infection of the transparent membrane (conjunctiva) that lines the eyelid and covers the white part of the eyeball. Causes include viruses, bacteria, and allergens. Symptoms are redness, itchiness, and gritty feeling or discharge that forms a crust. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment depends on cause: artificial tears for viral, antibiotic drops for bacterial, and antihistamines for allergic types.

Colorectal Cancer: Cancer that starts in the colon or rectum, often beginning as benign polyps. Risk factors include age, diet, and family history. Symptoms include a persistent change in bowel habits, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain. Diagnosis is confirmed via colonoscopy and biopsy. Treatment involves surgery (colectomy), chemotherapy, and radiation therapy depending on the stage.

Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD): A mental health disorder impacting the way a person thinks and feels about themselves and others. Causes involve environmental factors (trauma) and genetics. Symptoms include intense fear of abandonment, unstable relationships, impulsive behavior, and mood swings. Diagnosis is clinical based on DSM-5. Treatment primarily involves dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) and sometimes medications for symptom management.

Strep Throat: A bacterial infection that can make the throat feel sore and scratchy. Caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria. Symptoms include sudden throat pain, pain when swallowing, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. Diagnosis is via Rapid Antigen Detection Test or throat culture. Treatment requires a course of antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin) to prevent complications like rheumatic fever.

Raynaud's Phenomenon: A condition causing some areas of the body, such as fingers and toes, to feel numb and cold in response to cold temperatures or stress. Caused by vasospasms narrowing small arteries. Symptoms include color changes in skin (white to blue to red) and stinging pain upon warming. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves keeping warm and calcium channel blockers for severe cases.

Ankylosing Spondylitis: An inflammatory arthritis affecting the spine and large joints. It is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 gene. Symptoms include chronic pain and stiffness in the lower back and hips, especially in the morning, which can lead to spinal fusion ('bamboo spine'). Diagnosis involves MRI of sacroiliac joints. Treatment includes NSAIDs, physical therapy, and biologics (TNF blockers).

Bell's Palsy: Sudden weakness in the muscles on one half of the face. Caused by inflammation of the facial nerve (CN VII), often viral (Herpes Simplex). Symptoms include rapid onset of mild weakness to total paralysis on one side of the face and facial droop. Diagnosis is clinical after ruling out stroke. Treatment often includes corticosteroids (prednisone) and antiviral drugs.

Impetigo: A common and highly contagious skin infection that mainly affects infants and children. Caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Symptoms include red sores on the face, especially around the nose and mouth, which burst and develop honey-colored crusts. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves topical antibiotic cream (mupirocin) or oral antibiotics for widespread cases.

Hyperlipidemia (High Cholesterol): A condition characterized by high levels of lipids (fats) in the blood, including cholesterol and triglycerides. Risk factors include poor diet, obesity, and inactivity. It is generally asymptomatic but increases risk of heart disease and stroke. Diagnosis is via a lipid panel blood test. Treatment includes lifestyle changes and statins.

Aortic Stenosis: Narrowing of the valve in the large blood vessel branching off the heart (aorta). Causes include calcification with age or congenital heart defects. Symptoms include breathlessness, chest pain (angina), and fainting (syncope) upon exertion. Diagnosis is confirmed by Echocardiogram. Treatment for severe cases is valve replacement (SAVR or TAVR).

Gestational Diabetes: Diabetes diagnosed for the first time during pregnancy (gestation). Caused by placental hormones blocking insulin action. Symptoms are often absent but can include thirst and fatigue. Diagnosis is via the Glucose Tolerance Test (GTT) between 24-28 weeks. Treatment focuses on diet and exercise; insulin or metformin is used if blood sugar remains high.

Testicular Cancer: Cancer in the testicles, rare overall but the most common cancer in American males between ages 15 and 35. Symptoms include a lump or enlargement in either testicle, a feeling of heaviness in the scrotum, and dull ache. Diagnosis is via ultrasound and tumor marker blood tests (AFP, beta-hCG). Treatment typically involves orchiectomy (removal of testicle) followed by surveillance or chemo/radiation.

Erectile Dysfunction (ED): The inability to get or keep an erection firm enough for sexual intercourse. Causes are physical (heart disease, diabetes) or psychological. Symptoms are persistent trouble getting an erection and reduced sexual desire. Diagnosis involves physical exam and blood tests (testosterone). Treatment includes PDE5 inhibitors (sildenafil, tadalafil), lifestyle changes, or implants.

Septic Arthritis: A painful infection in a joint that can come from germs traveling through the bloodstream or from a penetrating injury. Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause. Symptoms include extreme discomfort and difficulty using the affected joint, swelling, redness, and fever. Diagnosis is via joint fluid aspiration (arthrocentesis). Treatment is an emergency involving IV antibiotics and joint drainage.

Measles (Rubeola): A highly contagious infectious disease caused by the measles virus. Symptoms include high fever, cough, runny nose, and Koplik's spots inside the mouth, followed by a full-body rash. Diagnosis is clinical and confirmed by IgM serology. Treatment is supportive (vitamin A, fluids); prevention is key via the MMR vaccine.

Huntington's Disease: A rare, inherited disease that causes the progressive breakdown (degeneration) of nerve cells in the brain. Caused by a CAG repeat expansion in the HTT gene. Symptoms include involuntary jerking movements (chorea), muscle problems, and cognitive decline. Diagnosis is via genetic testing. Treatment is symptomatic (tetrabenazine for chorea); there is currently no cure.

Gastritis: Inflammation of the protective lining of the stomach. Causes include infection with H. pylori, injury, regular use of NSAIDs, and excessive alcohol. Symptoms include gnawing or burning ache in the upper abdomen, nausea, and vomiting. Diagnosis is via upper endoscopy. Treatment involves antacids, H2 blockers, or proton pump inhibitors to reduce acid.

Lung Cancer (Non-Small Cell): The most common type of lung cancer. Major risk factor is smoking. Symptoms include a new cough that doesn't go away, coughing up blood, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Diagnosis is via CT scan and tissue biopsy. Treatment depends on stage and molecular markers, including surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy.

Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) Infection: An inflammation of the colon caused by the bacterium C. difficile. Often occurs after recent antibiotic use. Symptoms include watery diarrhea 10 to 15 times a day, severe abdominal cramping, and fever. Diagnosis is via stool toxin test. Treatment involves stopping the inciting antibiotic and starting oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin.

Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis): A painful condition that occurs when tendons in the elbow are overloaded, usually by repetitive motions of the wrist and arm. Symptoms include pain and burning on the outer part of the elbow and weak grip strength. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment includes rest, ice, NSAIDs, physical therapy, and sometimes bracing.

Osteoarthritis (OA): The most common form of arthritis, occurring when the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of the bones wears down over time. Risk factors include age, obesity, and joint injury. Symptoms include pain, stiffness, tenderness, and loss of flexibility, most often in hands, knees, and hips. Diagnosis is via X-ray (joint space narrowing) and MRI. Treatment involves physical therapy, NSAIDs, and joint replacement surgery for end-stage disease.

Chlamydia: A common sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Often asymptomatic, but can cause cervicitis, urethritis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) if untreated. Symptoms include painful urination and discharge. Diagnosis is via nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) from urine or swab. Treatment consists of a course of antibiotics such as doxycycline or azithromycin.

Narcolepsy: A chronic sleep disorder characterized by overwhelming daytime drowsiness and sudden attacks of sleep. Caused by a lack of the brain chemical hypocretin (orexin). Symptoms include excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone), and sleep paralysis. Diagnosis is via Polysomnography and MSLT. Treatment involves stimulants (modafinil) and antidepressants.

Hepatitis B: A serious liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV). Transmitted through contact with infectious body fluids. Symptoms range from mild illness to chronic liver failure, including jaundice, fatigue, and dark urine. Diagnosis is confirmed by serologic markers (HBsAg). Treatment for chronic cases involves antiviral drugs (entecavir, tenofovir); prevention is available via vaccination.

Bulimia Nervosa: An eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors like vomiting (purging), excessive exercise, or laxative use. Driven by body image distortion. Symptoms include inflamed throat, worn tooth enamel, and dehydration. Diagnosis is clinical per DSM-5. Treatment combines nutritional counseling, psychotherapy (CBT), and SSRIs (fluoxetine).

Spinal Stenosis: Narrowing of the spaces within the spine, which can put pressure on the nerves that travel through the spine. Most often occurs in the lower back and neck due to osteoarthritis. Symptoms include numbness, weakness, and pain in the legs that worsens with walking and improves with leaning forward. Diagnosis is confirmed by MRI or CT. Treatment includes physical therapy, steroid injections, and decompression surgery.

Cervical Cancer: Cancer arising from the cervix. Almost all cases are caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Early stages are asymptomatic; later symptoms include vaginal bleeding after intercourse, pelvic pain, and bloody discharge. Diagnosis is via Pap smear screening followed by colposcopy and biopsy. Treatment involves surgery (hysterectomy), radiation, and chemotherapy.

Hiatal Hernia: A condition where the upper part of the stomach bulges through the large muscle separating the abdomen and chest (diaphragm). Causes include age-related muscle weakness or increased abdominal pressure. Symptoms include heartburn (GERD), regurgitation, and difficulty swallowing. Diagnosis is via barium swallow or endoscopy. Treatment involves acid-reducing medications; surgery is reserved for large, symptomatic hernias.

Aplastic Anemia: A rare condition in which the body stops producing enough new blood cells (pancytopenia). Caused by damage to the bone marrow from autoimmune attack, radiation, or toxins. Symptoms include fatigue, high risk of infection, and uncontrolled bleeding. Diagnosis is via bone marrow biopsy. Treatment involves immunosuppressants, blood transfusions, and bone marrow stem cell transplant.

Myopia (Nearsightedness): A vision condition in which people can see objects near to them clearly, but objects farther away are blurry. Caused by the eyeball being too long or the cornea being too curved. Symptoms include eyestrain, headaches, and squinting. Diagnosis is via a standard refraction exam. Treatment includes corrective lenses (glasses/contacts) or refractive surgery (LASIK).

Rabies: A deadly virus spread to people from the saliva of infected animals. The virus infects the central nervous system. Symptoms start with fever and progress to agitation, hydrophobia (fear of water), confusion, and paralysis. Diagnosis is often post-mortem in animals; human diagnosis uses skin/saliva tests. Treatment is post-exposure prophylaxis (vaccine + immunoglobulin) immediately after a bite; it is almost always fatal once symptoms appear.

Periodontitis: A serious gum infection that damages the soft tissue and destroys the bone that supports the teeth. Caused by poor oral hygiene and plaque accumulation. Symptoms include swollen/puffy gums, bleeding while brushing, bad breath, and loose teeth. Diagnosis is via dental exam measuring pocket depth. Treatment involves scaling and root planing, antibiotics, and flap surgery.

Hypoglycemia: A condition in which blood sugar (glucose) level is lower than standard range. Common in diabetics taking too much insulin. Symptoms include shakiness, sweating, confusion, irregular heart rhythm, and dizziness. Diagnosis is blood glucose < 70 mg/dL. Treatment involves immediate consumption of high-sugar foods or drinks (15-15 rule) or glucagon injection for severe cases.

Varicocele: An enlargement of the veins within the loose bag of skin that holds the testicles (scrotum). Caused by valve failure in the pampiniform plexus. Symptoms include a dull ache in the testicle or a mass that feels like a 'bag of worms'. Diagnosis is clinical and confirmed by ultrasound. Treatment is usually surgical repair (varicocelectomy) or embolization if it causes pain or infertility.

Pleural Effusion: A buildup of fluid between the layers of tissue that line the lungs and chest cavity. Causes include heart failure, pneumonia, and cancer. Symptoms include chest pain, dry cough, and shortness of breath (dyspnea). Diagnosis is via Chest X-ray or CT. Treatment focuses on the underlying cause and therapeutic thoracentesis (draining fluid) to relieve breathing.

Panic Disorder: A type of anxiety disorder characterized by repeated, unexpected panic attacks (intense fear). Causes include genetics and stress. Symptoms involve rapid heart rate, sweating, trembling, shortness of breath, and a feeling of impending doom. Diagnosis is based on DSM-5 criteria. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and medications like SSRIs or benzodiazepines.

Tinea Pedis (Athlete's Foot): A contagious fungal infection that affects the skin on the feet. Caused by dermatophytes that thrive in damp environments. Symptoms include a scaly red rash, stinging, and burning between the toes. Diagnosis is typically clinical or via KOH preparation. Treatment involves over-the-counter topical antifungal creams (terbinafine, clotrimazole).

Hemochromatosis: An inherited disorder that causes the body to absorb too much iron from the food you eat. The excess iron is stored in organs, especially the liver, heart, and pancreas. Symptoms include joint pain, abdominal pain, fatigue, and darkening of skin. Diagnosis is via transferrin saturation and ferritin blood tests, and genetic testing (HFE gene). Treatment is regular phlebotomy (blood removal).

Infectious Endocarditis: An infection of the heart's inner lining (endocardium), usually involving the heart valves. Bacteria enter the bloodstream and attach to damaged areas of the heart. Symptoms include fever, heart murmur, fatigue, and Janeway lesions. Diagnosis involves Duke criteria (blood cultures and echocardiogram). Treatment requires high-dose intravenous antibiotics for several weeks and possibly valve surgery.

Delirium: A serious disturbance in mental abilities that results in confused thinking and reduced awareness of the environment. Causes include severe illness, medication toxicity, infection (UTI), or surgery. Symptoms are rapid onset of confusion, disorientation, and hallucination. Diagnosis is clinical (CAM assessment). Treatment involves addressing the underlying trigger and supportive care.

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): A progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, leading to loss of muscle control. The cause is largely unknown (sporadic), though some cases are genetic. Symptoms include muscle twitching, weakness in a limb, and slurred speech, progressing to paralysis. Diagnosis is via EMG and exclusion of other conditions. Treatment is supportive; Riluzole and Edaravone can slightly slow progression.

Uterine Fibroids (Leiomyomas): Noncancerous growths of the uterus that often appear during childbearing years. Causes involve genetic changes and hormones (estrogen/progesterone). Symptoms include heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and frequent urination. Diagnosis is confirmed by pelvic ultrasound. Treatment ranges from observation and hormonal therapy (GnRH agonists) to surgery (myomectomy or hysterectomy).

Pertussis (Whooping Cough): A highly contagious respiratory tract infection caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis. Symptoms include a runny nose followed by severe hacking cough spells that end with a high-pitched 'whoop' sound. Diagnosis is confirmed by PCR testing of a nasopharyngeal swab. Treatment involves macrolide antibiotics (azithromycin) to reduce transmission; prevention is via the DTaP vaccine.

Retinal Detachment: An emergency situation in which the retina pulls away from the layer of blood vessels that provides it with oxygen. Causes include trauma, extreme myopia, or aging. Symptoms include the sudden appearance of floaters, flashes of light, and a curtain-like shadow over the visual field. Diagnosis is via dilated fundus examination. Treatment requires immediate surgery (vitrectomy, scleral buckle) to preserve vision.

Pericarditis: Swelling and irritation of the thin, sac-like membrane surrounding the heart (pericardium). Often caused by viral infections or autoimmune disorders. Symptoms include sharp, stabbing chest pain behind the breastbone that gets better when sitting up and leaning forward. Diagnosis involves ECG changes and friction rub on auscultation. Treatment typically involves NSAIDs and colchicine.

Syphilis: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact. Caused by Treponema pallidum. Symptoms progress in stages: a painless sore (chancre), followed by a body rash, and potentially leading to damage to the brain/nerves (neurosyphilis) if untreated. Diagnosis is via blood tests (RPR, VDRL) and specific antibody tests. Treatment is a specific dosage of penicillin injection.

Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD): An inherited disorder in which clusters of cysts develop primarily within the kidneys, causing them to enlarge and lose function over time. Symptoms include high blood pressure, back or side pain, and blood in urine. Diagnosis is via ultrasound or CT scan and genetic testing. Treatment focuses on controlling blood pressure; end-stage disease requires dialysis or transplant.

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: A cancer that starts in white blood cells called lymphocytes. It is more common than Hodgkin lymphoma. Symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Diagnosis is confirmed by lymph node biopsy. Treatment depends on the subtype (aggressive vs. indolent) and usually involves chemotherapy (e.g., CHOP regimen) and immunotherapy (rituximab).

Gastroparesis: A condition that affects the stomach muscles and prevents proper stomach emptying. Common in long-standing diabetes (diabetic gastroparesis) due to vagus nerve damage. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting undigested food, and early satiety. Diagnosis is via Gastric Emptying Study (scintigraphy). Treatment involves dietary changes (low fiber/fat) and motility agents like metoclopramide.

Seborrheic Dermatitis: A common skin condition that mainly affects the scalp (dandruff). Caused by yeast (Malassezia), genetics, and stress. Symptoms include scaly patches, red skin, and stubborn dandruff. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves medicated shampoos (ketoconazole, selenium sulfide) and topical corticosteroids or antifungal creams.

Pre-eclampsia: A pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and signs of damage to another organ system, most often the liver and kidneys. Occurs after 20 weeks of gestation. Symptoms include severe headaches, vision changes, and swelling. Diagnosis is via BP readings and urine protein tests. Treatment involves close monitoring and medication; delivery of the baby is the only cure.

Cholera: An acute diarrheal illness caused by infection of the intestine with Vibrio cholerae bacteria. Spread by contaminated water/food. Symptoms include profuse watery diarrhea ('rice-water stools'), vomiting, and leg cramps leading to rapid dehydration. Diagnosis is via stool culture or rapid dipstick test. Treatment is immediate rehydration (Oral Rehydration Salts) and sometimes antibiotics.

Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis): An upper airway infection that blocks breathing and has a distinctive barking cough. Usually caused by a virus (Parainfluenza). Symptoms include barking cough, stridor (noisy breathing), and hoarseness. Diagnosis is clinical; X-ray may show 'steeple sign'. Treatment usually involves cool air, oral steroids (dexamethasone), and nebulized epinephrine for severe cases.

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD): A severe type of muscular dystrophy that primarily affects boys. Caused by a genetic mutation preventing the production of dystrophin. Symptoms include frequent falls, difficulty rising from a lying position (Gowers' sign), and progressive muscle wasting. Diagnosis is via CK levels and genetic testing. Treatment is supportive using corticosteroids to slow muscle degeneration.

Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID): A severe form of dissociation, a mental process which produces a lack of connection in a person's thoughts, memories, feelings, actions, or sense of identity. Usually associated with severe childhood trauma. Symptoms include the presence of two or more distinct personality states. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment is long-term psychotherapy.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS): A group of inherited disorders that affect your connective tissues â€” primarily your skin, joints, and blood vessel walls. Symptoms include overly flexible joints (hypermobility) and stretchy, fragile skin. Diagnosis is via physical exam (Beighton score) and genetic testing. Treatment is supportive, focusing on physical therapy and protecting joints from injury.

Achilles Tendinitis: Overuse injury of the Achilles tendon, the band of tissue that connects calf muscles at the back of the lower leg to the heel bone. Common in runners. Symptoms include pain and stiffness along the Achilles tendon in the morning and pain after activity. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves R.I.C.E. (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation) and eccentric strengthening exercises.

Hyperparathyroidism: An excess of parathyroid hormone in the bloodstream due to overactivity of one or more of the parathyroid glands. Symptoms include fragile bones (osteoporosis), kidney stones, excessive urination, and abdominal pain. Diagnosis is via blood tests showing high calcium and high PTH levels. Treatment is usually surgical removal of the overactive gland(s).

Kawasaki Disease: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It most often affects infants and young children. Symptoms include high fever > 5 days, 'strawberry tongue', red eyes, and peeling skin on hands/feet. Diagnosis is clinical based on criteria. Treatment involves IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) and aspirin to prevent coronary artery aneurysms.

Gingivitis: A common and mild form of gum disease (periodontal disease) that causes irritation, redness, and swelling (inflammation) of your gingiva. Caused by plaque buildup. Symptoms include dusky red gums that bleed easily when brushing. Diagnosis is via dental exam. Treatment involves professional dental cleaning and improved oral hygiene.

Ulcerative Colitis: A chronic, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes inflammation and ulcers in the digestive tract, specifically the innermost lining of the large intestine and rectum. Symptoms include diarrhea, often with blood or pus, abdominal pain, and fatigue. Diagnosis is via colonoscopy with tissue biopsy. Treatment involves anti-inflammatory drugs (aminosalicylates), corticosteroids, and biologic therapies (infliximab).

Prostate Cancer: Cancer that occurs in the prostate. It is one of the most common types of cancer in men. Early stages are often asymptomatic; advanced symptoms include trouble urinating, blood in semen, and bone pain. Diagnosis is via PSA blood test and transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy. Treatment options include active surveillance, surgery (prostatectomy), radiation therapy, and hormone therapy.

Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA): Often called a mini-stroke, it is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. Caused by a temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain. Symptoms include sudden weakness, numbness, or slurred speech that resolves within 24 hours. Diagnosis is clinical with imaging (MRI) to rule out stroke. Treatment focuses on preventing future strokes using antiplatelets and statins.

Gonorrhea: A sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It infects mucous membranes. Symptoms include painful urination and abnormal discharge from the penis or vagina; it can be asymptomatic. Diagnosis is via NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). Treatment requires dual antibiotic therapy or a single high dose of ceftriaxone to combat resistance.

Adhesive Capsulitis (Frozen Shoulder): A condition characterized by stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint. The capsule thickens and tightens around the shoulder joint. Symptoms develop in stages: freezing (pain), frozen (stiffness), and thawing. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves physical therapy, NSAIDs, and corticosteroid injections to improve range of motion.

Trigeminal Neuralgia: A chronic pain condition affecting the trigeminal nerve, which carries sensation from the face to the brain. Caused by blood vessel compression of the nerve. Symptoms include episodes of severe, shooting, or jabbing pain that may feel like an electric shock on one side of the face. Diagnosis is clinical and MRI. Treatment involves anticonvulsants (carbamazepine) or surgery.

Scarlet Fever: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. Caused by Group A Streptococcus. Symptoms include a bright red rash that feels like sandpaper, a 'strawberry tongue', and high fever. Diagnosis is via throat culture. Treatment involves antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin) to eliminate the bacteria and prevent rheumatic fever.

Ovarian Cancer: A type of cancer that begins in the ovaries. Often goes undetected until it has spread within the pelvis and abdomen. Symptoms are vague: bloating, pelvic pain, difficulty eating, and urinary frequency. Diagnosis involves pelvic exam, transvaginal ultrasound, and CA-125 blood test. Treatment usually involves surgery (debulking) and chemotherapy.

Hyperhidrosis: Abnormally excessive sweating that's not necessarily related to heat or exercise. Can be focal (hands/feet) or generalized. Caused by overactive sweat glands. Symptoms include visible sweating soaking through clothes and skin maceration. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment ranges from prescription antiperspirants and iontophoresis to Botox injections or sympathectomy.

Strabismus (Crossed Eyes): A condition in which the eyes do not align properly when looking at an object. Caused by problems with the eye muscles or nerves. Symptoms include eyes that look in different directions, double vision, and depth perception loss. Diagnosis is via eye exam (cover test). Treatment includes eyeglasses, patching the stronger eye, or eye muscle surgery.

Postpartum Depression: A complex mix of physical, emotional, and behavioral changes that happen in some women after giving birth. Caused by a rapid drop in hormones (estrogen/progesterone) and sleep deprivation. Symptoms include severe mood swings, withdrawal from family, and difficulty bonding with the baby. Diagnosis is clinical (Edinburgh Scale). Treatment involves counseling and antidepressants.

Acute Bronchitis: Inflammation of the lining of the bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from the lungs. Usually viral in origin (following a cold). Symptoms include a cough producing thickened mucus, fatigue, and slight fever. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment is supportive (rest, fluids, cough suppressants); antibiotics are rarely needed unless bacterial infection is confirmed.

Kyphosis: An exaggerated forward rounding of the back. Can be postural or due to spinal abnormalities (Scheuermann's disease). Symptoms include a visible hump on the upper back, back pain, and stiffness. Diagnosis is via X-rays of the spine. Treatment depends on severity and includes physical therapy, bracing, or spinal fusion surgery for severe curves.

Thrombocytopenia: A condition characterized by abnormally low levels of platelets (thrombocytes) in the blood. Causes include leukemia, immune system problems, or medication side effects. Symptoms include easy bruising (purpura), superficial bleeding (petechiae), and prolonged bleeding from cuts. Diagnosis is via CBC. Treatment addresses the underlying cause; corticosteroids or platelet transfusions may be used.

Laryngitis: Inflammation of the voice box (larynx) from overuse, irritation, or infection. Usually viral. Symptoms include hoarseness, weak voice or voice loss, and dry throat. Diagnosis is clinical or via laryngoscopy. Treatment primarily involves resting the voice and hydration; corticosteroids are used only in urgent cases (e.g., for performers).

Placenta Previa: A problem during pregnancy when the placenta completely or partially covers the opening of the uterus (cervix). Symptoms include bright red vaginal bleeding without pain during the second half of pregnancy. Diagnosis is via ultrasound. Treatment involves avoiding pelvic exams, bed rest, and C-section delivery if the placenta does not move.

Sjogren's Syndrome: An immune system disorder characterized by two most common symptoms: dry eyes and a dry mouth. The immune system attacks the glands that make tears and saliva. Diagnosis involves blood tests (SSA/SSB antibodies) and lip biopsy. Treatment includes artificial tears, saliva stimulants, and immunosuppressive drugs (hydroxychloroquine).

Hypokalemia: A lower-than-normal level of potassium in the bloodstream. Causes include chronic kidney disease, diabetic ketoacidosis, and diuretics. Symptoms include weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps, and heart arrhythmias. Diagnosis is via basic metabolic panel (BMP). Treatment involves oral or intravenous potassium supplementation.

Meniere's Disease: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. Caused by fluid buildup (endolymph) in the labyrinth. Symptoms include recurrent vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Diagnosis is clinical and via audiometry. Treatment includes low-salt diet, diuretics, and injections of gentamicin or steroids into the ear.

Bladder Cancer: Cancer that begins in the cells (urothelial cells) lining the bladder. Risk factors include smoking and chemical exposure. Symptoms include blood in urine (hematuria), frequent urination, and painful urination. Diagnosis is via cystoscopy and biopsy. Treatment options include surgery (TURBT, cystectomy), intravesical therapy (BCG), and chemotherapy.

Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS): A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Often preceded by an infection (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni or flu). Symptoms include weakness and tingling in the extremities that quickly spreads, potentially paralyzing the whole body. Diagnosis is via lumbar puncture (high protein in CSF) and nerve conduction studies. Treatment involves plasma exchange (plasmapheresis) and high-dose immunoglobulin therapy.

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC): The most common type of skin cancer. It arises from the basal cells in the epidermis, usually due to sun exposure. Symptoms include a pearly or waxy bump, a flat flesh-colored lesion, or a bleeding sore that heals and returns. Diagnosis is via skin biopsy. Treatment includes Mohs surgery, excision, or cryotherapy; it rarely metastasizes but can damage local tissue.

Social Anxiety Disorder: A chronic mental health condition in which social interactions cause irrational anxiety. Causes include brain structure (amygdala) and environment. Symptoms include intense fear of judgment, avoidance of social situations, trembling, and sweating. Diagnosis is based on DSM-5 criteria. Treatment involves Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and medications like SSRIs or beta-blockers for performance anxiety.

Diabetic Retinopathy: A diabetes complication that affects eyes. Caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye (retina). Symptoms include spots or dark strings floating in vision (floaters), blurred vision, and vision loss. Diagnosis is via dilated eye exam and OCT. Treatment includes blood sugar control, laser treatment, and anti-VEGF injections.

Pyloric Stenosis: A condition in infants that blocks food from entering the small intestine. The pylorus muscle thickens and blocks the stomach outlet. Symptoms include forceful (projectile) vomiting, dehydration, and constant hunger. Diagnosis is via abdominal ultrasound showing the 'doughnut sign'. Treatment is a minor surgery called pyloromyotomy.

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM): A disease in which the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick (hypertrophied). It is often genetic. Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, and arrhythmias; it is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes. Diagnosis is via Echocardiogram and MRI. Treatment involves beta-blockers, septal myectomy, or an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).

Molluscum Contagiosum: A viral skin infection that results in round, firm, painless bumps. Caused by a poxvirus. Symptoms include small, raised, pink or white lesions with a dimple in the center. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment is often not necessary as it resolves on its own, but options include cryotherapy, curettage, or topical therapy to speed recovery.

Polycythemia Vera: A type of blood cancer that causes bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. Caused by a mutation in the JAK2 gene. Symptoms include itchiness (especially after warm baths), fatigue, and headache. Diagnosis is via blood tests (high hematocrit) and bone marrow biopsy. Treatment involves regular phlebotomy (blood removal) and medication like hydroxyurea.

Epiglottitis: A potentially life-threatening condition that occurs when the epiglottis swells, blocking the flow of air into the lungs. Often caused by Hib bacteria. Symptoms include severe sore throat, fever, drooling, and leaning forward to breathe (tripod position). Diagnosis is via lateral neck X-ray ('thumb sign'). Treatment is an emergency: securing the airway (intubation) and IV antibiotics.

Pheochromocytoma: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue. It releases too much epinephrine and norepinephrine. Symptoms include episodes of high blood pressure, heavy sweating, headache, and rapid heartbeat. Diagnosis is via urine/blood tests for metanephrines and CT/MRI. Treatment involves alpha-blockers to control BP followed by surgical removal of the tumor.

Trichomoniasis: A sexually transmitted infection caused by a parasite (Trichomonas vaginalis). Symptoms include foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching, and painful urination; men are often asymptomatic. Diagnosis is via microscopic examination of discharge or NAAT. Treatment involves a single dose of oral metronidazole or tinidazole for both partners.

Shin Splints (Medial Tibial Stress Syndrome): Pain along the shin bone (tibia). Caused by repetitive stress on the shinbone and connective tissues, common in runners. Symptoms include tenderness, soreness, or pain along the inner side of the shinbone and mild swelling. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves rest, ice, and modifying exercise routines.

Hyperemesis Gravidarum: A severe type of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy. Unlike morning sickness, it causes severe dehydration and weight loss. Cause is linked to rapidly rising HCG levels. Diagnosis is based on weight loss (>5% pre-pregnancy weight) and ketonuria. Treatment involves intravenous fluids, electrolytes, and antiemetic medications (ondansetron, promethazine).

Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): The most common type of primary liver cancer. Occurs most often in people with chronic liver diseases like cirrhosis or Hepatitis B/C. Symptoms include upper abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Diagnosis is via liver imaging (CT/MRI) and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels. Treatment ranges from resection and transplant to ablation and chemotherapy.

Salmonella Infection (Salmonellosis): A common bacterial disease that affects the intestinal tract. Humans become infected most frequently through contaminated water or food. Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps within 8 to 72 hours. Diagnosis is via stool culture. Treatment is usually fluid replacement; antibiotics are reserved for severe cases or immunocompromised patients.

Torticollis (Wry Neck): A condition in which the neck muscles contract, causing the head to twist to one side. Can be congenital or acquired (spasm). Symptoms include limited range of head motion, headache, and neck stiffness. Diagnosis is clinical. Treatment involves physical therapy, stretching, heat, and sometimes botulinum toxin injections.

Hypopituitarism: A rare condition in which the pituitary gland fails to produce one or more hormones. Causes include tumors, head injury, or Sheehan's syndrome. Symptoms vary based on the missing hormone but include fatigue, weight loss, and low libido. Diagnosis is via hormone stimulation tests and MRI. Treatment involves lifelong hormone replacement therapy (e.g., cortisol, thyroid hormone).

Presbyopia: The gradual loss of the eyes' ability to focus on nearby objects. It's a natural, often annoying part of aging (usually starts mid-40s). Symptoms include a tendency to hold reading material farther away and blurred vision at normal reading distance. Diagnosis is via basic eye exam. Treatment includes reading glasses, bifocals, or conductive keratoplasty.

Ganglion Cyst: A noncancerous lump that most commonly develops along the tendons or joints of the wrists or hands. The cause is unknown. Symptoms include a round, fluid-filled lump that may be painful if it presses on a nerve. Diagnosis is clinical or via transillumination. Treatment is often observation; aspiration or surgical removal is used if painful.

Rubella (German Measles): A contagious viral infection best known for its distinctive red rash. It is dangerous for pregnant women (congenital rubella syndrome). Symptoms include mild fever, headache, and a fine, pink rash. Diagnosis is via serologic testing. Treatment is supportive; prevention is highly effective via the MMR vaccine.
